summary.seg: This manuscript contains the Commentary on Ptolemy's Handy Tables (Canones) attributed to Stephanos of Alexandria (6th-7th century CE). As in other exemplars of the tradition of this text (see Lempire (2011), pp. 244-248), the emperor Heraclius is indicated as the author, but this attribution has been rejected by scholars.

The codex was copied in the 17th century from two manuscripts: pp. ii, 1-2 were copied from Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Cromwell 12 ; and pp. 3-133 from Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Savile 51
(Lempire (2016), pp. 47-48).
After p. 133, two folded paper leaves have been inserted, perpendicular to the other leaves, and bear astronomical texts written in Arabic.

msItem.title: Epigram on Ptolemy's Handy Tables
msItem.rubric: p. ii Ἐπίγραμμα εἰς τοὺς προχείρους κανόνας
msItem.incipit: p. ii Δέρκεο ταύτην βίβλον, ἧς γε πατὴρ Πτολεμαῖος
msItem.explicit: p. ii οὔνομ' ἀκούειν κανὼν κλῆσιν δ' ἑποίμην αὐκεῖ.
msItem.note: Under the text there is a note by the scribe, saying that he copied the epigram from another exemplar: Haec ex alio manuscripto codice de astronomia descripsi

The same epigram is found in Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS grec. 2492 , ed. by J.L. Heiberg, Claudii Ptolemaei opera quae extent omnia, 2: 'Opera Astronomica Minora' (Leipzig 1907), p. cxlviii.

In the manuscript the text is attributed to Heraclius, Emperor of the East, approximately 575-641 Emperor Heraclius , but this attribution has been rejected by scholars (see Lempire (2011), pp. 244-248)
msItem.title: Commentary on Ptolemy's Handy Tables
Commentarium in Ptolemaei canones
msItem.rubric: p. 1 Ἄνχιδος ἐστὶν ἡ βίβλος Ἡρακλείου
msItem.incipit: p. 2 α΄. Ὅσα δεῖ προειδέναι τοὺς ἀρχομένους τοῦ κανόνος. Ὅτι ἡ σύστασις τῶν κανόνων
msItem.explicit: p. 133 νῦν καὶ ἀεὶ καὶ εἰς τοὺς αἰῶνας τῶν αἰώνων, ἀμήν.
msItem.note: The text is preceded on p. 1 by a table of contents
Ed. J. Lempire, Le commentaire astronomique aux Tables faciles de Ptolémée attribué à Stéphanos d'Alexandrie (Louvain-la-Neuve, 2016).

support.material:
Western paper, folded in quarto. Watermarks:
ff. left pastedown-[b], ff. [c]-[e] Pro Patria with countermark GR surmounted by a crown, in a circle, in the gutter, the watermark is not entirely visible, but it is comparable to the type Heawood Pro Patria 3700 , which is dated to 1747 in England (these are later endleaves).
pp. i-ii, 1-133 Coat of arms with an unidentified motif (wheel?) ( ca. 55 ca. 40 ) in the gutter.

foliation.p: Pagination in brown ink, original to the production of the manuscript, in the centre of the upper margin of the leaves, from 1 to 133 (the number 134 written on f. [iii] recto has been deleted). After p. 3 there is a blank unnumbered page ([3a]). Modern pencil pagination, i-ii, on the external upper corner of an endleaf contemporary to the text block. After p. 10, the original foliation reads 8; the correct page number, 11, has been added in pencil. After p. 107 there is a blank unnumbered page ([107a]). After p. 45 there is an unnumbered page ([45a]), where the text has been completely erased with oblique lines in brown ink. Modern pencil pagination from 134 to 137 on the folded paper leaves inserted between p. 133 and f. [iii]. Two unnumbered later endleaves at the beginning (ff. [a]-[b]) and three (ff. [c]-[e]) at the end of the manuscript (the upper part of ff. [c]-[d] and of f. [e] and the right pastedown have not been cut: only ff. [c] recto, [d] verso, and [e] recto are visible in the digital copy of the manuscript). ff. [a]-[b] + pp. i-ii + 1-3, [3a], 4-45, [45a], 46-107, [107a], 108-133 + 134-137 + ff. [iii] + [c]-[e].

collation.p: The leaves have been sewn very tightly and the quires are not numbered, therefore it has not been possible to ascertain the quires' structure.

supportDesc.condition: The leaves have not been trimmed regularly, the edges are now worn. The leaf formed by pp. 132-133 is detached from the book-block, together with the two folded leaves added to the manuscript. The binding is damaged on the spine.

layoutDesc.layout:
A single column; the number of lines varies from 22 to 37. The lines are passim traced in pencil.
ca. 165-180 130

handNote.p: ff. 1-133 Hand A: the text has been written by a single hand, prοbably by a scribe of western European origin, in a minuscule script, uprιght, of regular size.
The text is written in a brown ink, initials in red.

p. ii Hand a. Another minuscule script, by a western European scribe. James suggested that this hand could be the one of Patrick Young, but the script is different, see e.g. Young's script in MS Trinity College, MS O.1.36 .

decoDesc.decoNote: Thick initials in ekthesis, in red ink, see e.g. p. 131.
The text comprises tables, see e.g. pp. 106-107.

additions.p: On the left pastedown, in the upper left corner, are written, in brown ink, the old marks C.61 and no. 193, and the present shelfmark, O.1.19. Near these, is written an older shelfmark, which has been erased, O.3.26.

On p. i are written, in brown ink, the old mark C.61, and a note about the manuscript's contents, Heraclii Imperatoris Commentarius in Ptolemaei Canones προχείρους, idemque de Paschate Christiano. Liber emendate scriptus, rarus, ineditus.

binding.p: Western modern binding. Paper cover over pasteboards; parchment on spine, on which are glued three paper labels with the shelfmark, O, 1, 9. 210 160 17
binding.condition: The spine is split and damaged in the upper part.

physDesc.accMat:
After p. 133 two folded paper leaves have been inserted, perpendicularly to the other leaves of the manuscript, and contain texts written in Arabic and a few diagrams:
pp. 134-135 ( ca. 390 160 ). This leaf, now folded twice, was originally folded in two at a different point, and the text has been written on both sides from the folding line downwards. On p. 134, directly after the original folding line of the leaf, there is a note in Latin indicating the title of the text following in Arabic, and its author, Incipit libellus Hypsiclis de ascensionibus, ἀνέκδοτος; on the same page, after the text in Arabic, another note in Latin by the same hand indicates its end, Finis libelli Hypsiclis de ascensionibus.
pp. 136-137 ( ca. 260 ca. 190 ). On p. 136 there is a title in Latin, Incipit liber Theodosii de diebus et noctibus; the leaf, moreover, is numbered by the same hand Pag. ia ; on the same leaf, in the lower part, there are some notes and calculations by the same hand, written perpendiculalry to the text in Arabic. On p. 137, near the upper edge, there is a note indicating that this is the last page, in Latin, Pagina ultima; after some lines of text in Arabic, there is another indication in Latin, Finis libri Aristarchi de corpore luminarium (scil. Solis et Lunae); notes in Latin by the same hand follow.

origin.p: The manuscript was copied in the 17th century, probably in the latter part, in England: the text was copied from two manuscripts - Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Cromwell 12 and MS Savile 51 - which at the time were already in Oxford (see Lempire (2016), p. 48).

provenance.p: The manuscript was part of the collection of the antiquary Thomas Gale (ca. 1635-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1635?-1702 (no. 196), Regius professor of Greek at the University of Cambridge, High Master of St Paul's School and Dean of York (see James (1902), pp. xix seqq.): no. 6072 (238) in the list of Thomas Gale's Greek manuscripts in E. Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (1697) (p. 190).
The manuscript was subsequently part of the collection of Thomas's son, the antiquary Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744 .

history.acquisition:
It was donated to Trinity College Library by Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744
in 1738. On p. ii is pasted the Trinity College Library bookplate. On pp. ii and 133 there are stamps of Trinity College.

recordHist.source: Description (2021) draws partly on M.R. James, The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College Cambridge (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1902), vol. 3, pp. 22-23.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.
